question.title: How to use JAXB custom bindings to convert List<LangStringWrapper> to Map<String, String> during XJC code generation?
question.body:
I'm trying to use JAXB with XJC to generate Java classes from a complex XSD. Specifically, I want to map an XSD structure that uses a repeated LangString element into a Map<String, String> in the generated Java classes, rather than the default List<LangStringWrapper>.

How can I properly define XJC custom bindings so that all LangString elements are generated as Map<String, String> using a JAXB adapter or any other approach to get a Java class generated with Map instead of List? Any other logic or approach is also appreciated.

I want a generic approach, if possible, to avoid hardcoding for each element. Any help resolving this, especially with a working example, would be greatly appreciated.

Here’s the relevant small section part of my XSD:

<xsd:complexType name="LangString">
  <xsd:simpleContent>
    <xsd:extension base="xsd:string">
      <xsd:attribute ref="xml:lang" use="required"/>
    </xsd:extension>
  </xsd:simpleContent>
</xsd:complexType>

<xsd:complexType name="ClassName">
  <xsd:sequence>
    <xsd:element name="prop1" type="xsd:string"/>
    <xsd:element name="prop2" type="LangString" minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
    <xsd:element name="prop3" type="xsd:string"/>
  </xsd:sequence>
</xsd:complexType>

Java class generated by JAXB (current output):

protected List<LangStringWrapper> prop2;

Required output:

protected Map<String, String> prop2;

I have created a custom wrapper and a custom adapter:

LangStringWrapper.class:

import jakarta.xml.bind.annotation.XmlAccessType;
import jakarta.xml.bind.annotation.XmlAccessorType;
import jakarta.xml.bind.annotation.XmlAttribute;
import jakarta.xml.bind.annotation.XmlValue;

@XmlAccessorType(XmlAccessType.FIELD)
public class LangStringWrapper {

    @XmlValue
    private String value;

    @XmlAttribute(name = "lang", namespace = "http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace", required = true)
    private String lang;

    public String getValue() {
        return value;
    }

    public void setValue(String value) {
        this.value = value;
    }

    public String getLang() {
        return lang;
    }

    public void setLang(String lang) {
        this.lang = lang;
    }
}

LangStringAdapter.class:


import jakarta.xml.bind.annotation.adapters.XmlAdapter;

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.LinkedHashMap;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.Map;

public class LangStringAdapter extends XmlAdapter<List<LangStringWrapper>, Map<String, String>> {

    @Override
    public Map<String, String> unmarshal(List<LangStringWrapper> list) {
        Map<String, String> map = new LinkedHashMap<>();
        if (list != null) {
            for (LangStringWrapper item : list) {
                if (item.getLang() != null && item.getValue() != null) {
                    map.put(item.getLang(), item.getValue());
                }
            }
        }
        return map;
    }

    @Override
    public List<LangStringWrapper> marshal(Map<String, String> map) {
        List<LangStringWrapper> list = new ArrayList<>();
        if (map != null) {
            for (Map.Entry<String, String> entry : map.entrySet()) {
                LangStringWrapper wrapper = new LangStringWrapper();
                wrapper.setLang(entry.getKey());
                wrapper.setValue(entry.getValue());
                list.add(wrapper);
            }
        }
        return list;
    }
}

My Attempted custom-binding.xjb I tried the following (and many variants):

<jaxb:bindings xmlns:jaxb="https://jakarta.ee/xml/ns/jaxb"
               xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
               xmlns:xjc="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/jaxb/xjc"
               version="3.0">

    <jaxb:globalBindings typesafeEnumMemberName="generateName">
        <!-- Map xsd:date to java.time.LocalDate instead of XMLGregorianCalendar during java class generation -->
        <jaxb:javaType name="java.time.LocalDate" xmlType="xs:date" parseMethod="java.time.LocalDate.parse"/>

        <!-- Map xsd:datetime to java.time.LocalDateTime instead of XMLGregorianCalendar during java class generation -->
        <jaxb:javaType name="java.time.LocalDateTime" xmlType="xs:dateTime" parseMethod="java.time.LocalDateTime.parse"/>

        <!-- Map xsd:gYear to java.time.Year instead of XMLGregorianCalendar during java class generation -->
        <jaxb:javaType name="java.time.Year" xmlType="xs:gYear" parseMethod="java.time.Year.parse"/>
    </jaxb:globalBindings>

      <jaxb:bindings schemaLocation="JsonLdSchemaXSD.xsd" node="/xs:schema">
          <!-- Use wrapper class for LangString type -->
          <jaxb:bindings node="//xs:complexType[@name='LangString']">
              <jaxb:class name="LangStringWrapper"/>
          </jaxb:bindings>

         <!-- Apply adapter to all elements of type LangString -->
          <jaxb:bindings node="//xs:element[@type='LangString']" multiple="true">
              <jaxb:property>
                  <jaxb:baseType>
                      <xjc:javaType
                          name="java.util.Map<java.lang.String, java.lang.String>"
                          adapter="packageName.xsd.LangStringAdapter"/>
                  </jaxb:baseType>
              </jaxb:property>
          </jaxb:bindings>
      </jaxb:bindings>
</jaxb:bindings>

But this gives various errors:

  • Attribute 'adapter' is not allowed on element 'jaxb:javaType'

  • compiler was unable to honor this conversion customization

  • XPath evaluation results in too many target nodes

  • undefined simple type "LangString"

I’ve also tried using jaxb:javaType globally and locally, binding to both xs:element and xs:complexType nodes, without success.

How can I properly define XJC custom bindings so that all LangString elements are generated as Map<String, String> using a JAXB adapter or any other approach to get a java class generated with Map instead of List?

I want a generic approach, if possible, to avoid hardcoding for each element. Any help resolving this, especially with a working example, would be greatly appreciated.
